content.body: What's the canonical way to start a timer for some task in spec prose? I would guess calling https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/timers-and-user-prompts.html#timer-initialisation-steps, but that dfn isn't exported, and I'm certain we shouldn't call the actual DOM setTimeout() function from a spec algorithm...
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: What's the canonical way to start a timer for some task in spec prose? I would guess calling https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/timers-and-user-prompts.html#timer-initialisation-steps, but that dfn isn't exported, and I'm certain we shouldn't call the actual DOM setTimeout() function from a spec algorithm...

Dominic Farolino: "run steps after a timeout"

content.body: But to answer your question, it's fine to do that. Browsers will treat it as any other element, just without any given semantics. And web components are basically built on such "non-existent" elements, where you define their behavior with Javascript.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: But to answer your question, it's fine to do that. Browsers will treat it as any other element, just without any given semantics. And web components are basically built on such "non-existent" elements, where you define their behavior with Javascript.

content.body: Just note that they will render as inline elements by default.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Just note that they will render as inline elements by default.

      background-repeat: no-repeat;
